proof:
For the first part of the statement, we begin by expanding the right-hand side using the definition of a polymer's weight:
$$ q^{n_c} \prod_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = q^{n_c + |\Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)| - \sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} |V_G(\gamma)|} (e^\beta - 1)^{\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} e_G(\gamma)} $$
By definition, the disordered polymers of $F$ are the connected components of the graph $(V_C, F)$. This means the number of polymers, $|\Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)|$, is equal to $c(F)$, the number of connected components. Also, summing the number of vertices over all polymers, $\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} |V_G(\gamma)|$, gives the total number of vertices, $n_c$. Moreover, since every edge in $F$ is contained in a single polymer and the polymers do not overlap, the sum of the edges in each polymer, $\sum_{\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)} e_G(\gamma)$, must equal the total number of edges, $|F|$. Plugging these identities back into the expanded expression confirms the first part of the lemma.

Proceeding to the second part, we note that any disordered polymer with no edges has a weight of 1. Therefore, for any polymer of the form $\gamma = (\{v\}, \emptyset)$, the inequality presented in the lemma is trivial. Let us then suppose that $\gamma$ is a polymer containing at least one edge. Consider any $F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}$ for which $\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)$. We can define $F' := F \setminus E_G(\gamma)$, and we observe that $F' \ne F$. The components of the graph $(V_C, F')$ are identical to the components of $(V_C, F)$, with the exception of the vertices of $\gamma$. These vertices, which constitute the polymer $\gamma$ in $(V_C, F)$, are instead isolated vertices in $(V_C, F')$. As a result, the weight of $F'$ is related to the weight of $F$ by the equation $w_C(F') = w_C(F)q^{|V_G(\gamma)|-1}(e^\beta-1)^{-e_G(\gamma)}$, which simplifies to $w_C(F)/w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)$.
Let $\Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma) = \{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}} \mid \gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(F)\}$. We can then write
$$ \pi_C^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma \in \Gamma^{\mathrm{dis}}(\cdot)) = \frac{\sum_{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} w_C(F)}{\sum_{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}} w_C(F)} \le \frac{\sum_{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} w_C(F)}{\sum_{F \in \Omega^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} (w_C(F) + w_C(F'))} \le \frac{1}{1+1/w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma)} \le w^{\mathrm{dis}}(\gamma). $$
